[h1] The layman's dome keeper [/h1]

I see some negative reviews comparing this to dome keeper, and yes it is obvious that inspiration was taken from that game; however, there are some massive differences. What I mean by the layman's dome keeper is that I feel that this game is much more casual. In dome keeper you always feel like you are racing against the clock. You have to make every moment in the mine count just to barely afford the next upgrade for your dome, just to scrape by the next wave, and you always feel regret over your upgrades wondering if you should have upgraded your mining equipment or your weapons, etc. Wall world, none of that. 

[h3] Mining [/h3]

Mines are not a giant sandbox for you to hopelessly dig through, there are barrier blocks you cannot pass, and when you clear a mine it comes out looking very cavernous. That is to say, you have a clear path to follow when digging. That compounded with the points you collect for digging and block means, more often than not, you will completely clear every block in a mine before going to the next mine. In dome keeper you will have to think more about where to mine to conserve the most amount of time, strip mining to efficiently search for ores, which makes sense considering you only have one mine as opposed to the MINES available to you on wall world's vertical surface. My point is, there is no mining fuss like the predecessor. It is much more lenient with you, and it lets you swiftly harvest the wall's natural resources before moving on to greener mines.

Another big thing with mining. Resources! Dome keeper only has three ores I believe, each with a clear purpose. Wall world has an absolute catalog of ores, which makes sense because there is a whole world to search for ores. In my opinion, I do think mining is too easy, and I think there should be a big mine in each 'biome' as opposed to many mines that are available for the player to lay waste to.

[h3] Combat [/h3]

Combat is pretty much the same.

[h3] Political Allegiances [/h3]

I felt that this game had a very obvious agenda that just kidding we are going to talk about the combat. In Dome Keeper, you always come out of each battle worse off. There is no way to avoid damage, and each damage point means you are irreversibly closer to death. You need to restore health points with cobalt, the rarest resource in the world your dome lies upon, and as you continue mining the cobalt just gets sparser and sparser, making it very clear that you will die to attrition if you cannot lock tf in and clear the relics. Wall World: Each mine has a different color that makes it apparent what resources will be available in the mine. In the early game, if you are low you can look for an emerald mine and mine a couple dozen and be good on healing for the rest of the run. 

In the late game with wall world, your character comes out of each run with upgrades that make you way better than when you started. Dome keeper has a similar thing where when you win you get more domes or equipment to swap out for your existing ones; however, on the wall you get to directly upgrade your existing equipment. Dome keeper lets you continue running with a novel feel each time due to the myriad of domes and equipments while wall world gives you upgrades to allow you to survive longer to reach further along the wall than you were previously capable of. This makes sense in the sense that there is essentially a new dimension in wall world that dome keeper is missing, the ability to physically change your scenario by picking up the dome and setting it somewhere else, and likely somewhere less hospitable. BUT, I think wall world takes it too far.

Wall world will give the late game player massive advantages, such as the ability to stomp on wall walking melee enemies, making them no longer a threat, or having a shield that regenerates every round at no cost at all, removing the health conservation you felt in dome keeper, if it had migrated over to this game at all. That is my qualms with this. At some points it upsets me, but again it does allow this game to be much more laid back of an experience.

[h3] Gameplay Loop [/h3]

Dome keeper lets the player use their available resources and their brainpower to effectively harvest ores in the mine and fend off natives from breaching the dome, but after the game you get more items and you are simply left to do the same thing again. Wall world expects you to die and keep replaying in order to win, and it expects you to die a lot. Every round you get points for mining which you spend on upgrades after you die; meaning, slowly you will get more capable at achieving your goals. This made me realize that Dome Keeper is missing a campaign sort of deal that you can sort of see in Wall World. 

[h3] Polish [/h3]

First thing I noticed playing this game was the movement. The player moves very sturdily; there is no smooth movement like most games. Maybe it's better, but it also doesn't really make sense. In my opinion the player would jump around the mines and have a jet back to boost himself, but in game it feels like the engineer isaac clarke guy moves like something out of scratch idk. Dome keeper has the player slide around, makes sense considering you are using jets. You don't stop the second you stop pressing down a movement key. A little thing that you get used to a couple hours in, but I'm trying to dig deep and I remember that bothering me.

The music in this game is great. It is very peaceful. There is one track that is really pleasing.

The artwork in this game is good, don't get me wrong; however, dome keeper has artwork that is just beautiful. It looks amazing, and I think that is the main thing people point out between these two games. This game has amazing details like the rain falling onto your dome vertically, I think that is really cool, but dome keeper did really nail the hostile planet setting quite well.

[h3] Final Thoughts [/h3]

I think both games are good. They are both fun. Dome keeper is a beautiful game. Wall world is easier to continue playing and dying in order to achieve my goals. In Dome Keeper if I die then i failed my goal, and am no closer to achieving it. I like it when the opposite happens, and this game does that. This game also lets you die and lets you play without really having to stress largely over time and dying. Dome keeper can be stressful, which can make it worse, but can also make it better. I think everbody should get both. 

 | Как человек который любит рогалики скажу что это не лучший представитель жанра, да и в целом игра почти во всех аспектах умудрилась вставить палки себе в колеса.
Начнём с того что очень глупо вставлять таймер который предупреждает о боссе (на это в игре нет никакой причины) при этом боссы это чуть измененная версия одного левиафана - скука. А после подбирания всех ключей этот босс вообще отключается я в чём смысл этого действия - непонятно. 
Гринд гринд и ещё раз гринд, после прохождения основной компании ты не можешь просто пойти в длс потому что там тебя будет уничтожать всё что движется, но при этом прохождение кампании не равно купить все предметы. Эти самые предметы буквально метапрогрессия которая не дает ничего нового просто повышая статы.
Длс в игру не привносит ничего нового кроме босса паука который действительно прикольный, но кроме этого опять же гринд, так ещё и сама локация в длс линейная что ещё больше урезает геймплей.
Как итог эта игра просто не должна быть рогаликом, а если она хотела бы быть им то как минимум ей надо изменить подход к боссам, структуре локации (ведь после прохождения кампании лока всё ещё не бесконечна и выфармив все пещеры у тебя геймплей буквально обрывается ни на чём) и сделать что-то с метапрогрессий, по хорошему убрать её вообще и добавить нормальные анлоки. | Cara, sou só eu que gostaria muito! Estou jogando a algumas semanas e adoro esse game, por favor não parem de trazer melhorias!! | 与Dome Keeper重合度80%的作品，单论操作可玩性上墙世界可能更胜一筹，但是boss战过于单一，局外也只有简单的各种能力加成，没有更多的初始角色或基地可供选择，作为类rogue还是差点意思 | Fun game with an addictive roguelike gameplay loop, and plenty of upgrades to buy and help you progress further each run.

The game is generally playable, but you can see that it's absolutely unfinished. 

TLDR: The "cult management" aspect is shallow and empty, not balanced in the slightest.
---------------------------------------------------
1. There's not nearly enough paths to evolve into. Right now it doesn't have a path for even every general theme of your symbol. (no dinosaur cult, no great old ones cult)

2. The depth of the theme you choose is not even closely enough for a management sim saying you are "Managing your cult". There's only 3 special rooms, 2 garments, and 1 wall colour for every theme, and none of them are really useful so you can complete the game forgetting about them, only doing tasks for your theme progression.

3. Your choice of theme comes only around the second half of the game which means that you will in every playthrough have to do the very same things you do every time.

4. At least the Peace Path (perhaps also other 2) doesn't really have any kind of occult or mystical in it. And that is considering the game has canonical mythology creatures (Mages in events, Ghosts in Spirit Room, etc.). The game feels like every other general management sim.

5. Actually, it feels even worse because after about an hour of play it just turns into a tycoon/idle game where only thing you do is wait and do nothing, because there is virtually no possibility of losing it after you've got at least some basics and you only sit around having the game on your second screen, waiting for something to happen.

6. The followers to cultists system is absolutely broken. Even after building every single room and having your reputation maxed out, the followers that come to you can still very much have very poor quality, and good ones are extremely rare. And you also almost never know their actual quality because even with the right room, only about 1 follower a day will open their traits to you which normally results in them being kicked out because their quality is lower than the Bikini Bottom.

In the end, if you want anything that feels like a cult simulator and not a generic management sim with a fleur of something magical, don't buy this game | The game starts out failry entertaining but the poor UI design will have you clicking all over the place once your cult grows to a large size. Adding more missions/events + reducing clicks by making more efficient UI menus would make this game much better and more engaging. | Amazing game, as soon as I understood the game mechanics it became awesome to play. | Honey, I Joined a Cult: Pure Management Chaos and Fun

Ever wondered what it’s like to run your own cult? Well, Honey, I Joined a Cult lets you live that dream in the funniest and most chaotic way possible.

This game is a mix of hilarious storytelling, quirky management challenges, and endless creativity. You get to design everything about your cult—its theme, its sacred objects, even the outfits your followers wear. It’s ridiculously fun to watch your compound grow as your followers (somehow) buy into your crazy ideas.

The graphics are cute and retro, which just makes the whole thing even more charming. But don’t let that fool you—there’s plenty of strategy involved. You’ll need to manage resources, keep your followers happy (or at least too busy to complain), and deal with all kinds of hilarious and random events that keep things interesting.

What really makes this game shine is the humor. It pokes fun at cult life in the best way, and I caught myself laughing out loud more than once. But it’s also super addictive—one minute you’re just tweaking your temple’s decor, and the next you’re building a global empire of believers.

If you love management games with a side of absurdity, this one’s for you. Honey, I Joined a Cult is a blast from start to finish.

No Reviews

I want to say that I enjoy "Survivor-Likes" a bit too much. I have played almost every version of them. (atleast it feels like it)

VS, HoT, Death Must Die, Deep Rock, Genesia, Army of Ruin and some more. Each 100 hours+.
Makes me want to believe, I can see the good and the ugly in these games.

Halls of Torment is in my opinion in the Top 3 of Survivor-Likes and even succeeds in almost every aspect of it's "father".

One of the major flaws (imo) I experienced in these types of games, is the end game. What happens if you unlocked everything. Upgraded everything to the max. 

Usually these games lose themselves in senselessness.



Halls of Torment has a very befitting name and for sure it reaches it's point of illogical endless progession too but they have found ways to make the gameplay, on the 1000x repeating maps, quite interesting. 

You have a good arrangement of characters, each (so they make it feel) with their handcrafted and thought-through designs. They feel very unique and you can experiment alot. 

On top of that add some Items, some of them are mandatory for specific builds but yet there's alot of freedom to experiment around because they managed to keep most of them very useful.

That alone already sold me for most of the time I enjoyed the game. 

If one goes further they have added a cute endless mode. Cute because I personally love endless modes but this one didn't hit me as hard as some other games. You can pay gold to get random debuffs on your next endless run. Which I think can be alot of fun but I enjoyed their "Artifacts" far more.

You can play the basic maps with a mutator but the good thing here is you can decide which ones and how many you take, though each artifact will buff enemies base-stats no matter which artifact you pick. (...and yourself by granting more xp.)

That is in which I have lost myself, enjoying this game just the last few weeks.

If you manage to debuff the hell out of your run and kill the bosses in the end you get a currency to endlessly upgrade your characters. 

Now the kicker: In other games you have 100 of the progression upgrade-thingies.
You apply it to one character. 
Now you have 0 upgrade-thingies. Here you can upgrade them all simultaneously.

Fcking broke my mind.

First I resetted all the stats before applying it to a different character, because I was so used to games robbing your time and making you upgrade all characters each on their own.

But in HoT even characters you "don't like" will become viable only by playing your favorite character.


Halls of Torment. A big YES!

Enjoy the suffering! | BUG不修内容不做就改你那平衡性，怎么这么多肉鸽游戏开发者都这个毛病 | Fun at first, but gets old pretty quickly.  The end game revolves around running standard levels with negative modifiers, in hopes of getting better gear and cash to use on the final dungeon.  The problem is that the negative modifiers really turn the game into a slog, and the final dungeon is pretty mediocre.  I do enjoy the core loop and the various skills, but I have no desire to play the same missions, but with reduced visibility, or invincible enemies, or lava constantly spawning on me, etc.  It's not a knock to the developers; they have designed the game they want.  Sadly, it's just not for me. | I have mixed feelings on this one. On one hand, it is only 6,66€, looks good and runs well. On the other hand, that is all it has going for it, yet it still sits at 95% positive reviews. This rating seems too far from what I think it deserves, so I want to shine some light on its weak points to help out those who got blinded by the visuals (you know who you are).

tl;dr: Game has no performance issues and looks like Diablo (which is 95% of its merit). Gameplay is unengaging and grindy and peaks at "not harsh anymore". Not good, far from fun, just "not as bad as it was starting out". 
If you REALLY need your survivor-like to look like Diablo, then go for it. Otherwise go for Holocure or Death Must Die (or Vampire Survivors) as they all outclass it in every aspect aside from maybe your personal preference in visual style.

Be warned that a long, rambling yap is following.
The game starts slow, as in "your character moves at a snail pace and barely clears the enemies" slow. Matches the visual style and the unforgiving gameplay of the era that its visuals draw from, but that's about as far as the compromise goes. Maps have a few different point of interests you can reach, but due to the movement speed you likely won't get to complete more than one set of them at a time during your first runs, if at all. Combat feels adequate, with some desperately needed stat increases on level up to make your first character not fall behind too far and maybe survive 10-15 minutes on your first try.
Go back to the camp and spend a few coins on meta upgrades to your stats. Rinse and repeat a few times until you get enough stats to have your character not feel crippled, but instead appropriate to have a chance at clearing the level. Repeat for 10 hours until you realize that the grind never stops and you have yet to reach the point where you feel strong instead of handicapped, and the game did not hit actual fun territory once during your playtime.

Sounds overly dramatic, but that is what my experience with the game was like. 
It is understandable for your power level to be too low for a chance to clear the first map on your first tries, but here it feels sadistic. You move slowly, barely get to pickup resources due to your tiny pickup range, and attack slowly. Once enemies start to come in at a faster pace it won't take long to die. It takes a few runs to grind enough stats to have enough power to clear, and even more if you want to get some QOL stats, such as movement speed and pickup range, just for gameplay to be less [i] tedious [/i]. The first map and its accompanying missions provide enough motivation and rewards to offer a quick increase in power level, but all that does is unveil the plethora of other systems the game has been graciously saving so you don't get swamped with too many grinds at once.
One at a time you get to unlock (and grind to upgrade) meta progression such as: more stats to upgrade, reroll and banish options on level up, items to equip, and also new classes. Just for those you will need to run maps plenty of times, not only do you collect currencies, the equipment you want to unlock only reaches your camp if you collect them during a run and then send it back, one at a time, during the level to save it, and thus have access to it in future runs. You need to sacrifice power during any given run in favor of meta progression since you lose a well needed upgrade to unlock it permanently. On its own that sounds fine, but it is so slow. You only get to do that for one item per run (at first? Could be upgradable, but who cares to play enough to find out), and with the amount and variety you want to build up for the roster of heroes, that is gonna take a LOT of runs you play just to collect items and send them back. And then do it again, but this time purposely pick an item that does not fit your class, but hasn't been unlocked. And then again. And there is no other option, such as playing well and getting to carry out all the items you carry. Only the one item you send back to camp, everything else collected is lost.

Is that bad? So bad that I would go out of my way to write a negative review?
No, but it's one of the more egregious systems that require running maps over and over. The real bad part is that running maps is not fun. The core gameplay that the meta systems loop you around is slow and unrewarding, and that is the actual sin.
I started out talking about the game feeling slow, which is due to the default movement speed, along with attack speed and no access to advanced skills. This gets better after all, since your gold goes into rectifying that. But then you complete dozens of runs and find out that the game is a different kind of slow aside from the meta grind: Actually clearing maps is an uninteractive waiting around until the time ticks down. Once you hit the desired power level to comfortably grind meta items, you get to enjoy not being threatened by mobs anymore. That is where you find out that leveling up is presenting you with a screen showing multiple rewards to pick from, yet there is no real decision to be made. It might have felt like it during the first map when every stat was lacking, and you had to assess which area was lacking most at any given moment, but later on those stat increases become less impactful. The real meat should be in the advanced skills you get to upgrade every few levels, yet there is not enough variety among their upgrade paths, or interactions between skills to force any actual decision making. Skills are just a different visual that enemies die to. No matter which one I committed to, the gameplay felt the same. The way you move and engage with enemies does not change depending on what you picked. It is easy to see the clear best option, and then it is back to waiting for another 5 level ups to pick another one. There is no crafting a build in this game, no theory crafting synergies, there is only choosing which skill you want to carry you through a level, and then investing in it once unlocked. 
And once you do, it doesn't even get fun. Even with a strong loadout and great items, you might be strong and delete enemies, yet not even this state is actually fun to be at. Enemies come at you too slow to make it satisfactory, so even the ideal endgame power level is just...not fun. After all the grinding to get past the painful early stats, and the grinding to unlock enough meta systems, and enough grind to earn meta currencies, you go into a run, auto pilot your "build", and the reward is watching enemies not kill you. You don't explode the screen, no shredding hordes of mobs that threatened you before. No happy brain chemicals. The game goes from "you feel slow and weak" to "you are not slow and not weak anymore". The best it gets is not being painful. Gameplay peaks at "not bad" instead of good, let alone actually fun. This is the real death sentence.

Torturous beginning that flows into a steady stream of meta systems that require grinding their currencies. A slog of repeating maps and doing runs that do not require actual decision making, and do not offer the depth to allow theory crafting build. All of that just to make a character reach a power level where you do not die, and do not even get any real satisfaction of looking at waves get annihilated, but instead just trickle in through the border of your screen before dying. A roster of characters that play too similar and not engage or synergize with skills either, so no real depth here either. Pick whoever has the best stats, and by the time you hit level 10 in the level, it's all the same.

This game encourages you to grind a boring repetition of levels and refuses to acknowledge good gameplay with meta rewards or even the basic satisfaction of "build goes brrrrrr". Painfully tedious at the beginning, slightly less tedious by the time you realize that is all it has, and drop it for a better game. But at least it looks like Diablo from 1997, right? | 越改刷着越累，一波削弱把比车轮高的给砍了，接下来砍什么？

[h1]Сначала человек изобрёл шахматы. Затем человек изобрёл дробовик, чтобы в этих шахматах можно было выиграть.[/h1]

Великолепное переосмысление самой переоценённой игры в истории, отправляется в список моих любимых рогаликов. Я в шоке от глубины проработки и как из такого простого концепта можно выжать столько игровых механик, которые генерируют столько неожиданных геймплейных ситуаций. Потенциал билдов более чем раскрыт, тащить можно чем угодно. Меты как таковой нету, бóльшая часть перков так или иначе полезная, так что всё в ваших руках и на высоких рангах майндгейм зашкаливает. Справедливости ради, чаще всего вас банально будут зажимать фигуры, потому что ходят они по несколько штук за один ход. Да сложно, да рандом душит порой, но тем не менее затягивает. Дал поиграть деду, он кончил. А у него уже лет 30 не стоит... Говорит о многом.

Из минусов хотел бы отметить дизбаланс прогрессии а также невозможность пропуска выбора. Тобишь, чёрные карты почти всегда уступают белым и ты регулярно обязан выбирать между двумя плохими наборами. Имбовые чёрные карты тоже есть, но на мой взгляд маловато элементарных стат-апов на фоне полутора десятка белых карт, которые откровенно руинят забег если ты их подбираешь. Чего только стоят Таймер, Хилящие офицеры, Стреляющие короли и Кошмарные Кони. Ну или игра наролит кучу фигур на доске и вдруг оказывается что оружие ниxepa не способно вынести прущий навстречу легион. Особенно это всё ощущается на высоких рангах, которые надо проходить молитвами нaxyй. 

[code]Стоит отметить, что игра довольно короткая и забег в среднем проходит за 7-15 минут, так что слив не столь фрустрирует как в каких-нибудь комплексных рогаликах, где по полчаса трайхардить приходится.[/code] 

Учитывая что игру относительно часто обновляют, жду когда добавят больше карт на урон, патроны и уменьшение разброса. И почините наконец эту хрень когда убиваешь фигуру позади которой стояла другая и тебя ваншотит перманентно. Что самое интересное, если убить преграждающую фигуру гранатой то ваншот не прокнет, но я вам этого не говорил... | This is exactly my kind of silliness. Shotgun King is a chess game except you only have your king left and he has a shotgun. If that makes you think "Wait a minute, that's not chess at all!" then you would be correct. The game only wears its chess influence only on the surface, the game actually is a turn-based strategy roguelike. You have to play through 12 rounds and defeat the final boss at the end. Each round your goal is to kill the white king. You can do this by firing your shotgun, each white piece have different amount of HP, pawns and knights have the lowest and the king has the most. Your shotgun has three main stats: firepower, range and firing arc. Firepower defines how many pellets your shotgun fires, each pellet dealing exactly one damage. Multiple pellets can hit the same target, can hit multiple targets or completely miss any target. There is some RNG involved here but the closer you stand to your target, the more likely you are to hit it. Range shows the maximum travel range of your pellets. Your firing arc shows the spread of your pellets, they will always be inside this arc. Shooting an enemy that stands directly before you will always make all pellets hit him. It's the same concept as in other shooting games, the shotgun is more powerful close range and loses its power the further you stand away. However, sometimes a wider spread might be beneficial to hit more pieces. There are some strategic decisions you can make here.
Shooting or moving will always pass your turn. White pieces will move on their turn and they can move multiple pieces at the same time. They have their own speed stat that defines how many turns they have to wait until they can move.
Moving will also reload your shotgun. This is important, so you can move outside of check and fire on your next turn.
Your shotgun has only limited ammo, which does regenerate but very slowly, so you don't want to kill every piece, you want to focus on the king but still deal with troublesome pieces.

After each floor you will come in contact with the roguelike mechanic of the game, the cards. You get a selection of two different black cards which help you for the rest of the run. These can be simple like more firepower, ammo or range but they also can give you completely new abilites like a melee attack that does not use ammo or grenades, that will hit multiple pieces but can also kill you.
Each black card is tied to a white card. These are upgrades for the white side. They can get more pieces, change how pieces move and give pieces more HP or speed. You will have to evaluate what upgrades you need but also what downsides you can endure in return. One white card that always appears is the white queen after floor 3. You can't escape her, she is everywhere.
Killing a non-pawn piece will give you an edge however. You get their "soul" which you can activate to move in the same pattern as the piece you killed. You can only store one soul but you can get black cards that allow you to store more or have some other synergy with it. These soul cards are best used to get out of check or close the distance to the white king.

The game is incredibly goofy with its concept but its also a challenging strategy game that will take you some time to master. And as you beat th egame, you will start to unlock new difficulty levels that add extra pieces at the start, improve the enemy AI and give the white king more HP. You can also unlock new shotguns that have different starting stats. There is a surprising amount of variety in this small game. The game still gets updates to this day, despite being almost three years old. It's funny, it's challening and it's the exact type of game to play at the evening after a long work day. | It was a great fun game with levels that get a little bit harder, and you can get different shotguns and after each round you pick a card that upgrades your side, and the enemy. The normal amount of turns in a round is maybe 20-30, and 9 rounds in the level and i think 8 levels. There is also endless and chase.
 | This game is a very fun strategy and roguelike game, i love the variety of cards for you and the enemy and the achievements have kept me playing for a bit now, definitely worth it for the price but would pick it up on a sale like I did. | Fun game, nice and easy but with just the right amount of strategy involved.

Reviews:
The game is very fun but it will never go out of early access, devs are very lazy or the business model sucks and they are out of funds. Almost the same state of the game was available 1 year ago. I thought buying the early access would speed up the process, but it seems game is going to the void. | It might be a bit controversial to say this, but I like this game more than the Hades series. I don't know exactly why, but something about this game makes me want to keep playing it and spend hours on it. Don't get me wrong, I loved Hades, but Death Must Die is a better alternative in my book. Not because it's too simple or easy to play. Death Must Die is a really challenging and hard game. Also, I love the easy pacing of this game, to be fair, yes it's a bit repetitive right now but it's still an early access game and the developers are working on pumping out new updates and keep adding new things to the game. Looking forward to the new updates. | Game is Good. It would be better if there is a Chinese version. | Only 2 levels right now - This game is awesome and I have been playing it a lot. I reached the end of the second level though and realized there are no more. Now what? I have gotten 20 some hours out of this game but this took most of the enjoyment out it for me. Kind of a let down unfortunately. | Honestly. It is a quite decent Survivor-Like.
Problem is their updating cycles. Updates feel like they take ages,
and that update introducing Mastery Trees really kicked it out for me.

It limited all characters to playstyles you get from their respective Mastery Tree.
Forcing characters to be played with certain attributes,
which you maybe didn't even want.

You have almost an unlimited, boundless variety of items. Too much if you ask me.
Some giving stats that are useless or do not explain how they work.

For example (if I remember correctly) you had the Attribute "+1 Power - Projectile"
Means all Abilities in the "Power-Class" get 1 Projectile.
One Power-Ability is an Aura and if I remember correctly it sadly didn't double the aura, no your "Power-Ability" needs to have a projectile so that your Attribute can function.

So often you get Items that are almost perfect but have that one trait that just goofs it all up.

Was fun the first few hours and I tried to find my fun after the update but I have lost my appetite.

And they released it 2023? What did we have like 2 updates that really changed some things?

I cannot recommend it anymore.

I love the concept of this game but it does get dull quickly, which is not what you should think for a game that only lasts about 10 hours. Only a few hours in and I started seeing the same conversations happening and I would just revisit the lighthouse on repeat whenever those freaks asked me to because they've decided reality TV is the best means of gazing at lighthouses and that's the only way to not get laid off. I do think this game is very funny and looks great.

There aren't many games like this one and if this matches your freak AND you understand it's flawed, then this game is worth a shot. But for your general viewing audience, just try watching Real Housewives or something. | This game has a good premise and fun mechanics. I actually look forward to see where the story takes me.

However, the game suffers from repetitive dialogue at parts where it doesn't make sense. Changing up the morning dialogue from season to season just a little bit would have gone a long way. 

Another glaring issue is the color palette. Bright, over-saturated pastels make this game difficult to play and watch as was noted over and over by those daring to check out my livestream. | I straight up do not understand the hate for this game. I loved it!! I bought it after it was mentioned on a Yahtzee video, and had a great time. 

I don't find the gameplay repetitive; if you are playing through the main storyline, you should be chasing different goals each time. If people are finding it repetitive, I'd recommend trying different cast members [spoiler]and making sure that you are talking to everyone at night.[/spoiler] There is also a fast way to end days, [spoiler]dying.[/spoiler] You can do this at pretty much any point. Just like real life!

I know I enjoyed seeing all of the interactions with different characters and the variations for each individual character. It was also a fun puzzle to see how I could get the most audience engagement at the same time. 

The ending does leave a lot unanswered, which is a bummer, but I still enjoyed my time. 

I'm replaying it now [spoiler]to get the second ending, [/spoiler]and by the way, I really recommend a certain ORDER OF OPERATIONS. Without spoiling, just. Just trust the [b]AL[/b]PHAB[b]E[/b]T when it comes to what CHOICES you might MAKE. Unless you want to start from the beginning. So yeah, the replay value is meh, but it's not as rough as others said. I'm still finding new dialogue and I'm enjoying the e[b]x[/b]tra hard mode now that I know how to please the audiences. 

Look, i[b]f[/b] you like a s[b]i[/b]lly little time with a bit of myste[b]r[/b]y, you'll have a ball! It's a fun little puzzle with funny writing, entertaining character[b]s[/b], a gripping gameplay loop, and an in[b]t[/b]riguing, if not fully fleshed out, mystery. I like it and am going to get it for my friend who loves reality TV. 

part of me also wonders if some of the hate may come from the children and losers who like to find random games and just trash them/complain about them being "too woke" bc the game has gay ppl lol | Game was fun but is unplayable because of crashing. Crashes so often I can't progress anymore. I wouldn't even buy this on sale. | Выглядит интересно. Находиться в игре было приятно до момента, как понял схему работы "съёмок" и закрытия квоты.
Ничего кроме 100% в игре для меня не осталось, а 100% выглядят как много ненужной работы.
Если есть деньги и хочется попробовать что-то странное -> Рекомендую.

В остальном, лучше найти проект с более глубоким геймплеем.

上手之后会立马显得重复度略高，而且局外成长太花时间，要体验到完整的内容很费劲。

其次在上强度之后，游戏会从模拟建设瞬间转化成微操资源管理，人力和资源的极致运用才能让你拿下胜利，你说肉鸽？什么肉鸽？哪有肉鸽？建设？哪有建设？

这不算充足的随机性除了能让你升血压并不能让你的体验得到提升，毕竟这个游戏所有的肉鸽收益基本都是有滞后性的，鲜少有立即生效却对你收益巨大的情况出现，游戏本身也是比起解决问题更倾向于让问题防患于未然，可以说基本都处于一种今日受苦而明日享福的循环，而人往往并不待见延迟满足，这也是城市建造类游戏的通病，随机性则让这一点被增幅了许多，毕竟脸黑一下的话你的精心布局很可能要到游戏尾声才得以找到key牌启动。

在真正上手游戏的中后期，本作特色的“肉鸽”“建设”属性可以说是基本等于没有（甚至肉鸽方面可能是负作用？），冲着这两点来的颇有几分受骗的味道。高强度下的资源匮乏和时间赛跑让游戏的建设属性约等于无，时间全花在拼尽全力管理有效利用资源上，而肉鸽属性正反馈不足，且低难度通解太多、高难度拿不到最优解血压又太高，负反馈很强导致肉鸽的设计很抽象。

相对的，游戏耐玩、结构与内容完整，微创新也不少，上手简单易懂，游戏内有明确的阶段性目标，能让城建玩的少的玩家不至于迷失方向不知道该做什么，每一局的目标不一样一定程度上保持了新鲜感都是值得肯定的优点。

总的来说是值得一个好评的，入手推荐史低，另DLC风评远不如本体，慎入。 | Against the Storm focuses on the best part of a city builder which is the first hours when you are in the building phase.  Against the Storm plays out differently every time because the buildings you start with are always different.   It is a well optimized game, with constant choices of risk vs reward, and enjoyable when you figure out work-arounds for meeting necessary resources, through supply chain management.

What I appreciate about Against the Storm is that there is never is a point where it gets too complicated with too much too deal with at one time.  The equivalent of the "Boss battle" is challenging and rewarding.  Graphic and sound design are excellent.

I've played over 650 hours and still not sick of it, so there must be something to this video game.  

Support these devs.  Eremite Games is a Polish developer consisting of six, and they really have created a real gem of a game, and they have been actively improving and polishing the game for more than a year after the day 1 release. | I genuinely started off liking Against the Storm, but the further you get into the difficulties the more tedious it gets, with additional negative modifiers and additional hoops to jump through to complete the session. Each seal completion really incentivizes you to play the next difficulty to get enough shards to complete the next seal to follow the metaplot, and lower difficulties may not get you the number of seals you need in time - additionally, the further out you go, the higher the minimum difficulty of the embarkment is, pushing the player to embark on those higher difficulty options. Why progress the seals other than metaplot? So you get more resources for the Citadel metaprogression. Which does things like add resources to your starting caravan so you can actually build some production buildings at the start, or adding a production building that let you make many key items - poorly, at high cost, but beneficial for the build chains so you are not fully reliant on RNG to get a building to complete the chain, or even adding bonuses to each race in your settlement like showing you where the first set of fields is where you can build a farm the first time you recruit a Human, so you don't have to spend half the session opening the wrong glades and never getting the constant food production that would provide. 

Except like many modern roguelite hybrids, this metaprogression is poorly balanced, and time consuming, which makes it feel like busywork rather than enjoyable on its own. It makes the higher difficulties less tedious to tackle (especially with some of the more helpful bonuses), but it just feels like an absolute chore to get through. Speaking of chores, they just add more chores without opening meaningful doors and mechanics past Veteran in terms of the difficulty options. The first three difficulties add mechanics each jump - after Veteran comes Viceroy, which is the same thing as Veteran with new forbidden and dangerous glade events to threaten your settlement and that the forest is more hostile by a multiplier of x3 instead of x2, but they don't do anything "new" really, they are just more of what you have seen before on earlier difficulties, and they just cost a ton of resources that you may not have been able to produce unless you have enough bonuses from the metaprogression tree and otherwise they apply so many negative benefits your game may actually end, such as the Stormbird which as far as I can tell by searching across the internet, people have been complaining is poorly balanced even with a good settlement for years. I don't just mean negatively either - the Stormbird applies an infinite storm effect, locking you to a year until you finish it (which you could delay), which is abusable in its own right if you were lucky enough to find it early. The Stormbird is just absurdly out of band in both directions and I cannot understand the intent of including it compared to every other event. I suppose that its very existence changes the logic pattern of whether you should open forbidden glades at all, but the higher difficulties disincentivize the opening of small glades due to hostility modifiers, so that just leaves dangerous glades if you do not want to starve but want to ensure a manageable event. What a forcible winnowing of the meta - it creates a very rote playstyle even though the apparent point of RNG building choice to create more unstable, dynamic push-and-pull gameplay. 

By the way, the tree also has a level attached - as you go through various sessions you get XP, when you level up you unlock new buildings and cornerstones (buffs) to show up in the game. THIS metaprogression mechanic is where the actual doors are opened for new build orders. Except its just as slow as the tree since its a blocker on the tree - without those later buildings and cornerstones, the game is not necessarily giving you the tools to win on higher difficulties. The amount of XP seems really low as well no matter the difficulty and even with completing various achievement challenges, which just exacerbates the issue.

I assume the decision not to bind those buildings and cornerstones to the higher difficulties and instead to a metaprogression level was so that you can use them on the lower difficulties and practice various build chains, but without overwhelming people when they start to play, and because of the complexity of creating a system that could both leave them default on the higher difficulties and then unlock them for use on the lower one once you cleared the higher one. Though perhaps they could have used their training missions for this. In all honesty the buildings beyond the first few levels matter less than the cornerstones, but they both add to how obnoxious the metaprogression system is - even if it is justified ludonarratively. 

In positives, I genuinely like the give and take between blight and production starting with the Veteran difficulty. I enjoy the season model and how each session naturally pushes you to modify your build chain on the fly or attempt to produce enough of your current resources to trade for the things you need to complete the Orders. I enjoy the fact that a session can take no more than one hour or maybe two at the higher speeds and therefore allows a bite-sized city building experience. I genuinely did get 30 hours out of it so I would say I got my money's worth, and I may play some more now and again, but anything that sufficiently annoys me more than it captivates me gets a negative review especially when the causes will not be immediately apparent to the player. | Let me preface this by saying that the game is very well made and I understand why so many people love it. I am not refunding it for any notable flaws.

For me specifically, when I play this type of game I want to dig in and work on one continuous settlement and make it grow over time, eventually getting to a point where I have this massive city that basically runs itself, giving me a primal sense of satisfaction that doesn't need to be felt again for roughly two years. But this game is a rogue-lite with some aspects of a mobile game, where you constantly restart a 'run', so to speak, unlocking stuff to make things more interesting for the next one. And though well-crafted, it's just not the kind of thing I'm looking for in a city-builder. | 与其说是城市营造或者基地建设，更像是有限资源管理游戏，不符合我的兴趣

Игра-выживалка  под волнами  монстров  типа  вампиров,  но с  менеджментом  инвентаря через добавление  ячеек  с  ростом  уровня  персонажа и  упаковкой  оружия и  брони в  этот  самый  инвентарь (каждый  предмет  имеет  собственную  конфигурацию). Из плюсов и  уникальных особенностей - этот самый  менеджмент  инвентаря. При  этом  в  игре  по сути всего одна  локация - каждый  заход на  любой  сложности - это  20 уровней  башни,  на  каждом  из которых нужно продержаться  определенное  время и  один  босс  на  20 ом  этаже. Способностей как  таковых у  персонажей  нет - их заменяет  оружие,  так  что  классы различаются  по большей  части  бонусами  к  тому  или  иному  показателю  и  многие  ощущаются  примерно одинаково. Подсказки  к  достижениям  довольно кривые - много где  не  указана  часть требований. К  примеру  достижение  на  3000 золота и достижение  на  заход на  10  этажей  с  меньше,  чем  10 золота  в  кармане мне  засчитали  только  после  разблокировки  класса  Короля после  прохождения  на  третьей  сложности,  хотя  доступны  они  с  самого начала  и  нигде  это  требование  не  указано. Достижение  на  прохождение  этажа  не сходя  с  места можно выполнить лишь классом   lancer,  хотя  в  требованиях это  опять же  не  указано.
В  целом  я  бы  поставил  игре  6-7  баллов  из 10. В  жанре  есть  довольно много более  интересных представителей типа  Soulstone  survivors, Death  must  die или  Nordic  Ashes. | This is a great simple game.  Some, but not much, skill (movement) is required (depending on your build).  The graphics are great, the weapon effects are awesome!  The floor scaling is well designed.  The itemization is phenomenal.  While this game does so many things well, I have a few suggestions:

1. Add additional music track(s).  The floor track is great, but 1 track only gets old quick.
2. Incorporate some kind of guidebook that explains what things are, how they work, etc.  I'm glad that you don't force a tutorial on players, but there's a small bit of learning curve, via trial and error that could be fixed if people could simply find a resource that explained what certain things are (for example, what drops from barrels, how # of inventory slots are obtained after each floor etc).

Those are the only major "flaws" if you call it that.  Otherwise, I'd love to see an infinity tower that lets you keep going beyond floor 20.  And more content!  Add more items.  Downloadable item packs, etc.  I really love this game, but want even more!   Great job, devs! | When you have backpack hero meets roguelite, you get God of Weapons.

Very unique , interesting game style & mechanics.

Hope to see more content from the devs!

Definitely money Worth!
Highly recommend! | Not memorable in the genre. Once you understand item system (like in few runs) it becomes boring for first 20-30 levels which consumes half an hour each run.
- You can literally just stay in middle and past the first 10-15 levels.
- Even after, you can easily past level 20 with minimal move right or left.
- You cant save between runs. If you need to quit its over

In short if you are not going to play like more than 1 hour for 1 run you cant play this game.
I rarely killed in the run, most of the times it past 1 hour or so and I got bored and need to quit because there is not save.
 | Controller bugs acknowledged by the Devs for over 1 year and still not fixed. Do not purchase this game until it's fixed.

Pretty fun if you like this style of game! I do think the graphics aren't as readable as something like Luck Be a Landlord though, which can slow the gameplay down a little. But there's some fun strategy to be found here! | Game devs and sheep: name a more iconic duo

Balanced and enjoyable deckbuilder with plenty of synergies and an engaging campaign full of unique challenges that push you out of your comfort zones. If you enjoy Luck be a Landlord, Luck Land, Lucky Mayor, or Endgame of Devil, you'll enjoy this. | Sat down to try out the game. Played for three hours. As a fan of Luck Be a Landlord, Endgame of Devil and emergent gameplay, I really dig this game!

18 hours in. Still enjoying the game BUT success IS HIGHLY dependent on RNG with little you can do to mitigate it, at least at 18 hours in. I have played the same battle over dozens of times only to come up short at the last boss. Difficult but enjoyable but I feel that it needs more ways to leverage the RNG and roll-overs for unit stats are sorely needed.

Deceive Inc. is a undercover "Battle Royale" where you disguise yourself as npc to extract the briefcase from a vault against other teams of players.

This game tested your mettle in how much of an NPC you can realistically look like while fooling the other players. It's sad that this game is no longer getting updated, but the player base for the game is basically gone at this point. It took me forever to find matches to complete all the achievements for this game.

My friends and I had a lot of fun setting up traps for others teams, or acting completely like NPC's and then taking them out from behind. It would be nice if they made the game at least F2P for a while so other people could experience the fun I had, but finding a match is almost impossible at this point. 

I'm still going to recommend it based on what it was, rather than what it is now. | It's a great shame this game has such a minuscule playerbase at the moment, it's a truly fun, creative and overall well-designed game.

The mix of stealth and tense chases is just as, if not more enjoyable than the combat, which is rather enjoyable itself. That said, it's best played among a group of friends in private matches as you'll very rarely find active players in matchmaking. | 🎭🔫 Deceive Inc. é um jogo de espionagem multiplayer que transforma você em um mestre do disfarce, onde mentir, enganar e manipular são tão importantes quanto puxar o gatilho. Se você já quis se sentir como um espião de filme, infiltrando-se disfarçado e eliminando inimigos sem que ninguém perceba, então esse jogo é pra você!

🕵️‍♂️ Missões Secretas e Traições à Solta
Aqui, você joga contra outros espiões em um ambiente cheio de NPCs, onde o objetivo é coletar informações, hackear sistemas e garantir a extração da maleta antes de todo mundo. O detalhe? Todo mundo está disfarçado e qualquer pessoa ao seu redor pode ser um inimigo esperando para te pegar desprevenido. Paranoia total!

🎭 Disfarce é a Sua Melhor Arma
O diferencial de Deceive Inc. é o sistema de disfarces. Você pode se passar por guardas, cientistas ou funcionários para acessar áreas restritas sem levantar suspeitas. Mas cuidado! Andar rápido demais, olhar para trás o tempo todo ou ficar parado em um canto por muito tempo pode fazer com que outro jogador perceba que você não é um NPC.

🔫 Espiões, Gadgets e Estratégia
Cada espião tem habilidades e equipamentos únicos, como dardos tranquilizantes, armadilhas, escudos holográficos e até armas para quando as coisas saem do controle. O jogo equilibra bem ação e furtividade, então você pode ser um espião super discreto ou sair eliminando todo mundo (mas, honestamente, isso nunca dá certo por muito tempo).

🤩 Pontos Positivos
✅ Gameplay estratégico e cheio de tensão.
✅ Sistema de disfarce bem-feito e divertido.
✅ Variedade de personagens e habilidades.

⚡ Pontos Negativos
❌ O matchmaking pode ser demorado dependendo do horário.
❌ Pode ser frustrante ser eliminado logo no começo da partida.
❌ O jogo pode parecer repetitivo depois de um tempo, se você não curte esse estilo de gameplay.

🔹 Nota pessoal: 8.5/10 – Deceive Inc. é um jogo perfeito para quem gosta de espionagem e estratégia. Uma mistura de Hitman com Among Us, onde cada encontro é um jogo mental e qualquer movimento errado pode ser o seu último!

⏳ Tempo médio por partida: 10-20 minutos. | I picked this up on sale after hearing that the studio is closing. This is a breath of fresh air that combines ideas from many other games into a very enjoyable experience. I hope it finds a way to live on, and I hope the devs land on their feet in another cool project. | This game is the most unique shooter currently available.

Really sucks then that Tripwire did basically nothing to advertise for it, resulting in low player-counts which eventually lead to the developers being shut down.

I will NEVER forgive tripwire for not giving this game the attention it rightfully deserved.

Make no mistake, this game didn't die because of balance, or poor choices on the devs part. The blame here lies solely on the publishers shoulders.

i have played a lot of games, for a long time. many different genres, design sensiblities, and art styles, across several decades, on so many different systems. from NetHack to Hades II, from SpaceChem to Cookie Clicker, from DOOM (1993) to DOOM (2016).

this, for my money, might be the best game ever made.

intuitively simple; exquisitely complex and deep. i have every achievement and still cannot see a future where i don't play this anymore. arguably, this video game's existence is a testament to the undying creativity of the human spirit --- that we make works of dear significance and utter perfection almost by accident simply by following those pursuits we enjoy most.

furthermore, here i am, inspired to write all this pseudopoetic drivel about a video game next to meme reviews by accounts pretending to be Goku or whatever. but i wouldn't be sitting here calling it the best game ever made if it didn't also drive me to write "the undying creativity of the human spirit" in a steam review

just buy it, and buy it again for whatever other platforms you have. it's really good | La ludopatía nunca había sido tan divertida, tal vez porque acá no pierdes dinero real. This game has two problems IMO:

1. No sauce. Game doesn't FEEL good to play
2. Blackjack is fundamentally a push your luck game. Here, going over means you get nothing but being beat by the dealer means you only lose the difference. This means that you're heavily incentivized to play safe and slow which isn't fun | It all started with Balatro... then Luck be a Landlord. Now here I am after buying the 2-pack with Ballionaire.. I'm in a gambling video game phase because: 1. they're relaxing and 2. they're more fun and wacky than the vanilla versions. Plus this one has a pretty fun plot with recurring characters that you don't see in some other gambling games. It's a lot to take in a first in this one, but it's funny to see all of the random types of cards they have in the game. I would recommend this to anyone who enjoys the games I mentioned above, poker night at the inventory, and the like. Give the free demo a shot! | Lost to rats, lost to a zombie, lost to a drunk, lost to middle-management. Beat a cheating devil! 21/21 would double down again! | 他のレビューの方の意見がまんまだったけど、まぁ同じ意見があると信憑性がますってことで

理想
・デッキ構築なんだからデッキ圧縮して21作りまくって勝つンゴね！
・いろんな楽しいテーマデッキで遊ぶンゴね！

現実

・一部を除いてルールは大体スッキリしてる、日本語訳の優秀さも相まって可読性でストレスを感じることはない | A game I'd love to give a neutral on. The concept is great, but it feels like right as my build engine really got going is when the game ends. Build variety shows promise in design, however I did feel constrained by the medium here. If you're looking for that Balatro itch to be scratched this offers at least a few hours of similar fun, but wasn't overly memorable for me.

Barkley is a good boi. 

This is a wonderful monster-catching game that scratches the itch of the original pokemon games, but manages to do something completely new and different. Instead of catching and summoning monsters, you record them and then transform into them. 

You bring a friend with you (Barkley is the only correct choice) who can also transform, and then you’re able to fuse both forms together to create a more powerful form that inherits the moveset of the two fused beasts. 

Moves are unlocked using “stickers” which can be removed from beasts and added to others as often as you like, which makes for some really unique combinations and lets you play the game your way. 

Also the soundtrack is boss. 

Oh and did I mention one of your companions is a doggo? His name is Barkley. He’s a good boi. He brings you sticks. | [h3]优点：[/h3]
战斗系统做的不错，能自己搭配技能，养小精灵；可以自己选择同伴一起冒险，跑图时忍不住想把所有怪物都抓一遍
[h3]缺点：[/h3]后期有点枯燥乏味，跑图时不小心碰到小怪会很折磨；没法看到每个怪的详细属性有点可惜，部分被动技能会在敌人都死完后还会触发动画，比较浪费时间；地图上各种解密跑酷开箱子然而奖励有时非常少，让人更觉得浪费时间了；少量LGBT元素
[h3]总结：[/h3]瑕不掩瑜，值得一试！7.5/10分

[h3]以上为个人观点，仅供参考[/h3] | Je suis littéralement tombé amoureux de ce jeu.

Je suis, comme beaucoup de gens, un grand fan de la licence Pok*mon. J'ai grandit avec sans m'en lasser pendant 25 ans. J'ai énormément de mal à aller vers les jeux pok*mon -like "type rétro" (coromon, etc) mais là je me suis laissé tenté, le gameplay m'intriguait.

Je ne regrette rien, ni la somme investit (y comprit les DLC), ni le temps passé dessus
 | Good characters, great combat and better music with a deceptive amount of content, though the endgame is a bit grindy. | Si vous aimez Pokémon, jouez-y.

Si vous n'aimez pas Pokémon, jouez-y.

Ce jeu change tout ce qui est frustrant dans Pokémon, et par là même c'est affranchis de l'étiquette de "copie de Pokémon" qu'ont beaucoup d'autres jeux du genre.

Vous ne faites pas monter de niveau des monstres que vous esclavagisez, [i]vous[/i] montez de niveau et vous ne prenez que l'apparence des monstres dont vous copiez l'essence dans des cassettes.

Faire monter l'affinité d'une cassette il suffit de l'avoir dans votre équipe, et toutes les cassettes gagnent le même nombre d'expérience que vous les utilisiez au combat ou pas. Le succès de faire monter l'affinité max pour toutes les cassettes disponibles (plus de 140) a été remporté par 2.5% des joueurs parce que c'est bien moins long.

Les combats sont équilibrés pour 2 personnes par équipe, sont rythmés par la gestion de points d'action que vous gagner au début de chaque tours et accumuler pour utiliser des attaques plus puissantes ou utiliser immédiatement, et vous pouvez fusionner temporairement n'importe quelle monstre avec n'importe quelle autres. 

Ca veut dire plus de 16 300 fusion différente, dessinées, et nommées. 16 300 fusion différentes avec 16 300 dessins différents et 16 300 noms différents, cohérents avec leurs monstres de base. C'est plus que tout les pokédex de toutes les générations additionnés.

Les 10 attaques pour une cassette maxée sont modulables comme des Légo. Vous avez juste à être hors combat et ouvrir le menu.

Le monde est bien plus ouvert et la progression libre que dans un Pokémon, et est aussi bien plus interactif. Vous voyez les monstres au lieu de tomber dessus au hasard dans les hautes herbes, et vous pouvez les éviter ou les chasser. Et vous utiliser les CS directement dans le monde, par pression d'une touche, comme dans un Métroid-Vania. Sans avoir besoin d'avoir un monstre avec la bonne attaque dans l'équipe.

Et puis si vous n'êtes pas encore convaincues, les interactions entre les types de monstres est beaucoup, beaucoup plus poussée qu'un bonus ou malus de dégât. Quelques exemples : 

- utiliser une attaque feu sur un monstre de type vent va créer un courant ascendant qui protège ce dernier de deux attaques (même un allier), utiliser une attaque vent contre un monstre feu vas l'éteindre ce qui va diminuer son attaque pendant trois tours.

- utiliser une attaque plante contre un monstre feu crée de la fumée qui augmente l'esquive de ce dernier, utiliser une attaque feu contre un monstre plante lui inflige toujours le statut brûlure.

- utiliser une attaque glace contre un monstre eau le parralise pendant un tour et lui donne le type glace pendant 3 tours, utiliser une attaque eu sur un monstre glace renforce sa défense pendant 3 tours

C'est tout ce que Pokémon aurais pus être sans les limitations technique de l'époque et avec un peut plus de créativité et des mécanique modernes plus fluides.

Un véritable banguer. La seul ombre au tableau est qu'il n'y a pas assez de musiques et qu'elles sont trop vite répétitives, ce qui est un comble quant des cassettes audio sont autant au cœur du jeu que les pokéballs.

[h3] Absolute cinema [/h3]

I want to like this game, but the truth is it feels the exact same 12 hours in as it does 30 minutes into it.  Maybe a slight bit faster, but not much.  

This is what building a game by the numbers feels like.  "We want each difficulty to be 10% more difficult."  That's what this feels like, and very little changes that.  The permanent upgrades you can get for each class are so small and insignificant that they may as well not exist.  They are often just 2 or 3 level upgrades, which you can get literally by the hundreds once you get going.

2.4/5 - Needs tuning.  So close to great, but not quite there. | omg this is amazing fun
you're basically a little turret (despite your character choice) and you have to kill the waves of enemies from each direction
can you survive 20 nights? 
it starts out seeming easy but it ramps up in a fun way
the upgrade paths are a cool way to do this instead of "choose one" like other roguelites
the presentation is on point, when it gets serious the music gets more intense and it's such a rush

this is a wonderful game for the price, get it you'll have fun | This is a neat game with a really fun idea as well as lots of things to unlock.

The gameplay loop itself is really simple, monsters come towards you from 4 different directions, you need to kill them.
Whether you'll be using arrows, mines, magic, minions, swords all depends on your chosen character and the talents you pick as the night progresses.

There's many different talents to find and many of them being unlockable. You can unlock new sets of talents by just doing runs with that character.
There's also challenges that unlock new talents or skins, though I am not a big fan of the skins since I'd rather have had something more serious and cool looking than the more goofy skins the characters get (at least the ones I have seen) but that's just my opinion).

This game is something you can play for 20-30 minutes every so often, it is quite fun and quite original :D | "Talented" was fun for a few hours, but it has what I might uncharitably refer to as "dim man's depth": it presents many choices but ultimately, subject to a few very basic common sense principles one could easily boil down to a rather simple set of algorithms (like selecting best "scaling of scaling"), there's very little by way of truly satisfying skill going on. Decent time sink, but fans of serious strategy will find themselves pondering "is this it?" because there's not much true player agency and only a rather basic sort of decision making. It's done well to "package" that limited bundle of choices in such a way that people who frankly aren't that bright will be convinced it's much deeper than it is though.

If you love the process of selecting skills much more than actually using them precisely or skillfully, you'll probably be extra likely to get some enjoyment here. This is definitely true for some people who just really love "builds". Prospective players should beware the tags, however (for anyone buying on that basis), I really wouldn't call this an action roguelike in any meaningful way. It would be much more accurately described as a roguelite autobattler that plays like something bordering on a TD with a very big emphasis on hard power mechanics and selecting upgrades for optimum raw power scaling.

As for me, while I had fun, the 8 hours I've put in now is already more than enough. I won my first however many runs maybe like 8 or something without any losses or serious difficulty and I don't know, there just really wasn't much to it getting on the right side of the optimisation problem it presented, and for me at least, nailing optimisation problems like this only really feels truly satisfying if I don't also feel like any random key pressing monkey could have pulled off much the same thing. Children and teens might get more mileage here than adult players I think, and ultimately a game being simple is not exactly a bad thing, it's just that like I said, I'd be a teensy bit weary about the accuracy of the user tags.

Talented is adding a serviceable piece of content to the market, so it's a lukewarm but amiable recommended / thumbs up from me. | 有趣而令人着迷的轻量级roguelike，虽然随机生成的技能树也无法抹平每局游戏中后期略显重复的体验，但对一个18r的游戏来说已经足够好了

ผมเห็นเกมนี้ครั้งแรกตอนที่จะซื้อ Planet of Lana แล้วจับมือกับเกมนี้ขายแพ๊คคู่ตอนที่ลดเหลือ 200 บาท พอเห็นราคาปุ๊ป รีบออกไปเติมตังมากดซื้อเลย รับรู้ได้จากที่เห็นทั้งสองเกมครั้งแรกว่า ผมจะชอบและสนุกทั้งสองแน่นอน Planet of Lana ก็ทำให้ผมชอบมากๆได้แล้ว มากับเกมนี้ดูว่าผมจะชอบได้แน่ๆมั้ย

[h2]ข้อดี/ชอบ[/h2]
-เกมเพลย์ ผมโคตรชอบโคตรมันส์ อย่างแรกที่แอบตกใจนิดนึงคือเกมแอบรุนแรงพอสมควรเลย เกมมาเป็นทั้ง open-world, top Shooter, Action adventure คือมาแม่งทั้งแอ็คชั่นเลย55 เซตติ้งเกมเป็นเกาะลอยฟ้า เพราะงั้นจะมีบู๊สองแบบจาก ที่เรายิงเองกับขี่เรือเหาะถล่ม อาวุธก็จะมีหลายแบบให้ใช้รวไปถึงยานเรือเหาะของเราด้วย ลักษณะการเล่นบางส่วนจะคล้ายแบบ Far Cry ที่เราต้องไปยึดเกาะต่างๆมาเป็นของเรารวมทั้งฟาร์มของไปในตัวด้วย แล้วย่งช่วงหลังๆจะทวีคูณความโหดที่มีพวกสัตว์ประหลาดออกมาเพ่นพ่าน เราก็ต้องคอยอัพทั้งอาวุธเรา อัพยานเกาะและก็ออกตามหาทั้งของอัพเกรดและสมบัติที่กระจายอยู่ทั่ว ซึ่งโคตรมันส์และโคตรจะเพลินสุดๆ เวลาได้ยิงทีนี่สะใจมากๆ แถมแต่ละเกาะก็มีพัซเซิลที่ทั้งยากง่ายกันไปซึ่งถ้าแก้ได้ก็ด้ของอัพพเพิ่มเติม ทำให้เราพยายามอยากจะสำรวจให้หมดซึ่งตรงนี้เนี่ยแหละที่จะดูดเวลาเราได้ดีเลย

-เนื้อเรื่อง ตรงนี้ก็สนุกไม่น้อย ด้วยความขัดแย้ง ความโหดที่ตรงนี้แอบตกใจเลยว่าเนื้อหาบางจุดนี่ก็น่ากลัวใช้ได้ แถมมีหักหลัง มีหักมุมจนเอาผมเหวอได้เลย แนะนำลองอ่านดู อาจไม่ต้องเก็บรายละเอียดหมดได้ถ้าขี้เกียจ เพราะตัวเนื้อเรื่องหลักก็น่าสนุกและน่าสนใจในโลกเกาะลอยฟ้าไม่น้อย

-ชอบที่ภาพมาเป็นพิกเซล แล้วก็ทำได้ดีด้วย โดยเฉพาะพวกโซนสัตว์ประหลาดนี่ทำออกมาได้น่ากลัวและก็ขนลุกดี และก็ตัวเอกเราน่ารักดีครับ ดูทั้งห้าวทั้งเท่ไปในตัว เรื่องงานภาพนี่ส่วนตัวล้วนๆเพราะชอบเกมภาพพิกเซล

[h2]ข้อเสีย/ไม่ชอบ[/h2]
-ตามสไตล์เกมประเภทให้เถลไถลได้ตามใจ คือ เนื้อเรื่องไม่เดิน ยังดีตรงที่บางส่วนจะกั๊กถ้าไม่ไปเล่นเนื้อเรื่องต่อแต่หลังๆไม่ค่ยมีและ ผมก็ฟาร์มมัน ยิงเที่ยวเก็บของสนุกจนลืมไปเลย กลับมาอีกทีลืมและให้ทำไรวะ55
-อันนี้ส่วนตัวคืองงนิดหน่อยตรงที่ บอสตัวนึงที่มาช่วงประมาณต้นเกมแต่โคตรยากกก ดีที่เกมมีรีเลือดให้นิดนึงถ้ายังไม่ตาย แต่บอสตัวที่เหลือทั้งเกมไม่ได้สู้ตึงมืออะไรเลย แล้วทำไมไอตัวนี้แม่งเล่นเอาหืดขึ้นคอ อันนี้ไม่รู้เป็นที่เกมหรือผมฟาร์มมาไม่ดี แต่ให้ไอตัวนั้นยากสุดเลย ยากกว่าลาสบอสอีกแล้วมาต้นเกมก็เลยงงหน่อยๆ 
-อันนี้ผมไม่ค่อยเป็นแต่ว่าคนอื่นมีแน่ๆคือ ช่วงกลางๆไปหลังเกมจะค่อนข้างฟาร์มลูปเดิมแล้ว เลยอาจจะมีเบื่อๆนิดหน่อย แต่พอเข้าช่วงเจอสัตว์ประหลาดอันนี้จะเริ่มตื่นเต้นและ แต่ช่วงระหว่างทางยอมรับว่ามีช่วงเนือยๆอยู่

[h1]Overall 8/10[/h1]
Black Skylands เป็นอีกเกมนึงที่สนุกและไม่ได้น่าผิดหวังเลย ความสนุกจากการได้สำรวจไปยังเกาะต่างๆ ได้บู๊ทั้งเดินยิงเองกับยิงเรือเหาะใส่กัน ความเพลินจากการได้ฟาร์มของมาอัพอูปกรณ์ทั้งอาวุธกับเรือเหาะ เนื้อเรื่องที่น่าสนใจและสนุกใช้ได้ อาจจะมีติดนิดหน่อยเรื่องอสบางตัวกับความซ้ำซากบางช่วง แต่ก็ยังเป็นเกมยิงฟาร์มของเพลินๆที่ดีมากๆเกมนึง แอบแนะนำตอนมันลดหรือซือแพคคู่กับ Planet of Lana เลยครับ คุณจะได้เกมน้ำดีสองเกมเล่นรวดเลย
 | It's entertaining for the time you spend with it, though it loses some steam towards the end.

If you like what you see from the trailer video and aren't looking for a masterpiece, I would say to go for it!

All that being said, it feels like a game where the developers ran out of time and pushed it out the door.  The narrative is bare-bones but functional, the combat it fine, the gameplay loop is entertaining enough.  But it constantly feels underbaked and that if the developers had put a little more time into it, this could've really been exceptional.

My hope is that the developers learn from this and that we see what this game could have been in one of their next titles.

Очевидно, вдохновленная Диско Элизиумом игра с концепцией "Библиотекаря" Михаила Елизарова, или тот самый случай когда у разработчика есть средства на реализацию, но нет собственных глубоких идей и способностей раскрыть замысел.

К сожалению, несмотря на потрясающий 3D визуал и очень красивую картинку, ставлю игре минус, так как написана она очень и очень плохо. Почему нельзя было выделить средства на хорошего нарративщика для такого амбициозного проекта? Непонятно. Просто поиграли в Диско и захотелось подзаработать? Окей, такое не в новинку, но как игроку обидно, ведь можно было просто уделить немного времени истории и текстам, что, как ни странно, очень важно в игре ПРО КНИГИ. Дизайн диалогового окна, к слову, тоже обработан довольно плохо и является очевидным вторичным продуктом от Диско.

Конкретно по минусам:
- жидко и бездарно написанные диалоги;
- слабый сюжет и проработка лора;
- иллюзия выбора, которая немножко плюет в лицо игрокам;
- слабая диалоговая система;
- много воды;
- боевки в стиле карточных смотрятся странно в изометрии;
- плохо проработанный главный герой -- у него нет своего голоса, подобные реплики мог написать любой;
- слабый нарратив подсказчика;
- очень мало смыслов при довольно хорошей основной задумке.

В очередной раз в играх пренебрегают нарративом и на выходе получается слабая пародия на хорошую игру. Если разработчики хотели просто заработать денег, то закончу здесь. Если же есть более высшие идеи, то желаю им исправить все недостатки и выкатить полноценную игру. | I'd recommend on sale! 

2/5 Stars if I was to give it a rating. 

Played on Steamdeck. 

The game is trying to be a few too many things at the same time and is I think maybe spread a bit too then as a result. 

What I liked: 
- The world building within the books. The spaceship and train books were really cool conceptually! 
- The art style, and overall aesthetic both visually and audibly. 

What I didn't like: 
- No fail state, not that I want this to be dark souls but if you present turn based combat the actual outcome of losing is completely null. You get kicked out of the book and the enemies you were fighting are more than often just gone, so its an easy win. 
- The combat isn't fun or engaging but a way to prolong your playtime by maybe 2 minutes. Its really boring. 
- The illusion of choice, often the game would give you dialogue choices, you would pick one, then another and then magically a third one would show up. It became predictable and eventually revealed itself to be linear in nature but presenting the illusion of choice. 
- The actual puzzles - I think some were kind of serviceable but mostly they were find the right thing to click, or item to use and then use it on the thing. Problem is, is that there was generally only one obstacle at any given time. On top of that, your NPC companion would often tell you what to do. Now there is a hint function, but I am stating that he would tell you sometimes before you even had a chance to maybe think about using it. 

Finally, the actual story conceptually is interesting. A guy with writers block, in a world that has these laws, does illegal thievery of items from books and brings them to and from the fictional world to his own world. Cool. Unfortunately the final act feels rushed, not dramatic, and felt frustrating when it just kind of wrapped up. 

I was hoping for more, but got a linear walking simulator with the illusion of choice, combat and puzzles. I love walking sims, literally got some characters from some tattooed on me, but due to being spread too thin and a rushed ending, I can only recommend this game on sale. | The Bookwalker тронула меня до глубины души. После неё действительно появилось чувство, что персонажи книг живые и всё чувствующие. Эта игра развивает эмпатию и сочувствие к "бездушным пикселям". Хотя лично для меня, геймера со стажем, это давно открытая истина. Я просто рекомендую всем поиграть в этот маленький шедевр. Такого геймплея я нигде раньше не видел, он уникален. | A lot of people are comparing this game with Disco Elysium. They are completely different games, just like Counter-Strike is different from Battlefield. Disco is huge and overloaded with dialogs and variety, Bookwalker is simple, cute point&click.

+ Visuals are very appealing and the worlds of books you visit are awesome (really made me willing to visit a bookstore more often)
+ Characters are "alive". I have no idea how at first glance a temporary character could actually make me feel emotions. (damn robots)

+ Simplicity, the game is not here to challenge you but to relax. You won't screw your character or loose by bad decision (at least I didn't).
-+ Variety, I do miss it but... at the same time I don't. Mixed feeling, think the variety would mess the simplicity.
